name: Thionyl dichloride

The addition of two chlorine atoms in thionyl chloride (SOCl2) should increase the melting point due to greater molar mass and enhanced van der Waals forces. However, the polar nature of the S-Cl bond and the possibility of intermolecular dipole-dipole interactions can lead to a higher decrease in the melting point, as they can disrupt the crystal lattice. Each chlorine atom may lead to an estimated decrease in melting point by -16°C.

- The chlorine atoms attached to the sulfonyl group also contribute to the melting point through increased molecular weight and polarity. Each chlorine might add approximately +20°C to the melting point.
